archdesc.bioghist: Arthur Delong Thomas, Jr. was born in Dearborn, Mich. on August 20, 1923. He married Mary Jean Armstrong on December 28, 1944. The couple had three children: son Tom and two daughters, Abbie and Amy. Arthur served as a member of the occupational force in Japan in 1945-1946, as part of the K Company, 303rd Battalion, 97th Infantry Division staioned at Camp Arthur on Honshu Island, Japan. Between September 1945 and February 1946 Thomas was an editor and columnist for "Honshu Pioneer," the first daily newspaper published for American G.I.s in Japan. In 1946 Thomas returned to the U.S. and received a B.A. degree from Harvard University and a M.A. in History from the University of Michigan. In 1954 he became a history professor at Henry Ford Community College in Dearborn, Mich., where he taught until his retirement in 1985. He passed away on November 22, 2004 at age 81.
archdesc.scopecontent: Collection contains 130 editions of the newspaper "Honshu Pioneer,"running from September 1945 to February 1946. The collection also contains an edited transcript of the newspaper, published by Thomas' son Tom Thomas in 2013. The volume also includes family background, personal remembrances and commentary about military history. The materials have great research value for those interested in the period of Allied occupation in Japan following World War II, especially regarding soldiers' experiences and perspectives.
